In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  To guide its approach to mainstreaming governance and capacity development in its 
operations,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  Second  Governance  and 
Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II)1 in July 2006 and the Medium-Term Framework and 
Action Plan for Integrating Capacity Development into Country Programs and Operations (CD 
Action  Plan) 2  in  January  2007.  The  ADB/Organization  for  Economic  Cooperation  and 
Development  (OECD)  Anti-Corruption  Initiative  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific  (the  ADB/OECD 
Initiative),3 launched in 1999 to set goals and standards for sustainable safeguards against 
corruption, has also contributed significantly to strengthening governance capacity in the region.  
 
2.  The  first  phase  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Governance  and  Capacity 
Development Initiative supported the implementation of GACAP II and the CD Action Plan, and 
provided continuing support to the ADB/OECD Initiative.4 With GACAP II and the CD Action 
Plan  moving  beyond  the  inception  stage,  ADB  will  focus  on  consolidating  lessons  and 
mainstreaming governance and capacity development in its sector operations. The design and 
monitoring framework for the second phase of the TA is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Under GACAP II ADB has adopted a risk-based approach to governance assessment 
and prioritizes three governance themes that are viewed as essential to poverty reduction and 
development  effectiveness:  public  financial  management,  procurement,  and  combating 
corruption. These three themes apply at the national and subnational levels, and in ADB priority 
sectors  in  its  developing  member  countries  (DMC).  ADB  has  completed  country-level  risk 
assessments for eight DMCs6 and 17 sector-level risk assessments in eight DMCs.7 Additional 
resources and technical support are needed to assist regional departments in implementing the 
GACAP II requirements during preparation of country partnership strategies (CPS). Twelve 
CPSs are scheduled for consideration by the Board of Directors in both 2009 and 2010. 
 
4.  The first phase of the TA supported the preparation of the GACAP II guidelines,8 which 
provide general guidance to ADB staff on the implementation of GACAP II, particularly on the 
risk-based approach. A source book, which was also prepared under the first phase of the TA, 
compiles existing governance tools and analytical frameworks to assist with the preparation of 
country-level  and  sector-level  risk  assessments. 9  During  the  next  phase  of  GACAP  II 
implementation, the emphasis will be on more specific guidance for preparation of sector-level 
risk assessments.

5.  The CD Action Plan calls for capacity development to be institutionalized in ADB's 
operations through a results-based CPS, which assists DMCs in addressing priority capacity 
gaps. Resources and technical support will be required to ensure capacity assessments are 
undertaken as part of the governance risk assessment process (nationally and in priority sectors) 
for the 24 CPSs scheduled for preparation in 2009–2010. Under the first phase of the TA, the 
Practical Guide to CD in a Sector Context 10 was prepared to guide staff in assessing capacity 
needs and formulating capacity development strategies, particularly in addressing key risks to 
development effectiveness identified in country and sector governance risk assessments. In 
response to a request from the Government of Pakistan, ADB supported a study of public sector 
capacity development with special reference to the delivery of pro-poor services. Study results 
were disseminated at the third High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness in Accra, Ghana in 
September 2008.  
 
6.  In preparation for the High Level Forum, more than 150 officials from 38 countries met at 
four Asia–Pacific subregional consultations. The consultations included representatives from 
diverse ministries, civil society organizations, and development partners. The resulting Accra 
Agenda  for  Action  highlighted  the  central  role  of  capacity  development  in  meeting  the 
commitments of the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness. At these consultations and the 
forum, there was resounding demand for support of national processes to localize the Paris 
Declaration and Accra Agenda. However, countries called for support to be less event-driven, 
longer term, and linked to country context. In response, ADB, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of 
Japan, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and the World Bank developed 
the  Asia–Pacific  capacity  development  for  development  effectiveness  (CDDE)  program  to 
support  partners  as  they  implement  the  Accra  Agenda,  strengthening  their  aid  policy  and 
accelerating the achievement of development results.11  
 
7.  The  ADB/OECD  Initiative  developed  an  anticorruption  action  plan  for  Asia  and  the 
Pacific, which set goals and standards for sustainable safeguards for regional cooperation 
against  corruption.12 In  2001,  17  Asian  and  Pacific countries13 endorsed  the  plan,  and  an 
additional  11  countries  and  jurisdictions14 signed  on  by  2008.  By  encouraging  continuous 
anticorruption  reforms—through  research,  publications,  technical  advice,  regular  regional 
forums,  and  information  sharing—the  ADB/OECD  Initiative  is  recognized  by  governments, 
development partners, civil society, and the private sector. The first phase of the TA supported 
the initiative's biannual conference on fighting corruption in Asia and the Pacific and provided 
initial financing for a review to assess the efficacy, continuing relevance, and future course of 
the initiative.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA's impact will be assisting selected DMCs in responding more effectively to 
governance  risks  at  the  country  and  sector  level.  The  TA's  outcome  will  be  identified 
governance, capacity development, and anticorruption priorities addressed by DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Assessments of governance risks and capacity development will provide DMCs with 
more focused diagnostics for prioritizing governance reforms and capacity development actions. 
In responding to the assessments, the risk management plans and capacity development action 
plans  will  provide  practical,  actionable  measures  to  address  major  risks  that  have  been 
identified. Good practice guidance for governance and capacity development will improve the 
quality  of  diagnostics,  enabling  DMCs  to  identify  the  actions  to  be  taken  to  strengthen 
governance capacity. By bringing together developed, middle-income, and weakly performing 
countries—supported by an advisory group comprising development partners, civil society, and 
the private sector—the ADB/OECD Initiative supports regional anticorruption efforts, fosters 
learning, and generates regional and country knowledge. The knowledge generated through the 
initiative not only supports DMC-led governance and anticorruption reforms, but also serves as 
an input to governance risk assessments. 
 
10.  Output  1:  Governance  Risk  Assessments  and  Risk  Management  Plans  Inform 
CPSs.  The TA will provide funds and technical support for preparation of governance risk 
assessments  for  selected  CPSs.  To  support  efforts  to  strengthen  quality  at  entry,  more 
emphasis will be placed on (i) the quality of risk management plans included in the CPS, and (ii) 
strengthening the integration of risk management plans and sector road maps. 
 
11.  Output 2: Sector Capacity Development Assessments and Actions Plans Inform 
CPSs. The TA will provide funds and technical support for preparation of capacity development 
assessments focusing on risk mitigation measures identified in the governance risk assessment. 
The  capacity  development  assessments  are expected  to  help  define  the scope  of  actions 
required to address major risks in the CPS governance risk management plans, improving the 
quality at entry of CPSs. 
12.  Output  3:  CDDE  Program  Supports  Government-Led  Capacity  Development 
Initiatives Across Asia and the Pacific. The TA will provide funds for the multidonor CDDE 
program designed to meet DMC government-led capacity development priorities to implement 
practical capacity development actions to further the Accra Agenda for Action.15 The CDDE 
program is organized around three key result areas: (i) signatories from Asia and the Pacific will 
achieve the Paris Declaration targets by 2010 and the Accra Agenda actions by the time of the 
fourth High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness in 2011, (ii) Asian and Pacific countries will 
establish  networks  with  each  other  that  will  improve  national  capacities  for  development 
effectiveness,  and  (iii)  Asian  and  Pacific  countries  will  contribute  to  the  institutional 
strengthening of the global aid architecture. These will be achieved by supporting activities in 
three  service  lines:  (i)  peer-to-peer  exchange,  (ii)  knowledge  management  and  help  desk 
services, and (iii) an assessment of capacity development needs and strategies to meet them. 
                                                 
15  This TA will provide funds for the CDDE first year's workplan. Subject to the results of the annual review, further 
funding will be sought for the CDDE workplan for the second and third years.

4   
 
13.  Output  4:  Good  Practice  Guides  Governance  and  Capacity  Development 
Initiatives. Building on the Guidelines for Implementing GACAP II, the TA will support the 
preparation of further guidance for ADB staff on sector-level governance risk and capacity 
development assessments and action plans. The first set of notes will focus on ADB’s priority 
sectors, as defined in the long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020).16 The 
notes will be informed by applied research on country and sector risk-based approaches to 
assessing public financial management, procurement, and combating corruption.17  
 
14.  Output 5: Implementation of the ADB/OECD Anticorruption Action Plan for Asia 
and the Pacific Strengthened. The ADB/OECD Initiative's strategy and work plan for 2009–
2010  builds  on  the  successful  approach  taken  since  1999.  The  strategy  articulates  the 
initiative’s vision, role, and goals for 2009–2010. It takes into account recent changes in the 
anticorruption  landscape  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  region  to  provide  member  countries  with 
targeted  assistance  in  their  fight  against  corruption.  Key  elements  of  the  strategy  are  (i) 
ensuring continual review of the progress of reform under the action plan, (ii) strengthening and 
expanding  partnerships  in  the  fight  against  corruption,  and  (iii)  developing  capacity  for 
anticorruption activities.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The cost of the TA, estimated at the equivalent of $2.05 million, will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program (TASF-IV) (equivalent to $1.55 
million)  and  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  ($500,000), 
supporting output 2. ADB will administer the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund grant. The 
TA proceeds will cover consulting services, training, seminars, conferences, surveys and other 
studies, and reports and publications. Indicative cost estimates and the financial plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency and will implement the TA. The Public Management, 
Governance  and  Participation  division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department, in collaboration with regional departments, will be responsible for TA activities for 
outputs 1, 2, and 4.  
 
17.  Activities under output 3 will be managed by the UNDP Regional Center in Bangkok, 
which  is  the  CDDE  program  secretariat,  and  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  Some 
development partners have committed to financing the CDDE program.18 It is proposed that, 
through this TA, ADB will provide $150,000 to the joint development partners' fund that UNDP 
will manage. An administrative arrangement between ADB and UNDP will be signed as set out 
in the memorandum of understanding between them,19 including an agreement that the CDDE

program funds will be subject to the internal and external audit procedures provided in UNDP's 
financial regulations, rules, and directives. ADB will be a member of the program steering 
committee which will receive progress reports every 6 months.20 The CDDE program supports 
DMCs in Asia and the Pacific, and the contributions of all participants are made jointly. However, 
a limited number of activities might occur in, or a consultant might be from, a non-ADB member

18.  The  activities  under  output  5  represent  ADB’s  ongoing  support  for  the  ADB/OECD 
Initiative. As in the past, ADB and OECD will have separate secretariat functions, and the TA 
will be implemented jointly under the guidance of the initiative’s steering group.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months, starting in May 2009. The TA will require 
international consultants (estimated 27 person-months) and national consultants (estimated 129 
person-months)  with  expertise  in  governance,  public  financial  management,  procurement, 
anticorruption  practices,  and  capacity  development  at  country  and  sector  levels.  Terms  of 
reference for consultants will be further specified when specific governance risk assessment 
and  capacity  assessment  diagnostics  are  identified  by  regional  departments  for  CPS 
preparation. Copy editors (30 person days) will also provide support. 
 
20.  Given the intermittence of the assignments and the variety of skills required, consultants 
will be recruited individually. Where appropriate, nongovernment organizations will be recruited. 
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements will be made in accordance 
the  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.21 All  TA-financed  goods  will  be 
procured in line with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve: 
 
(i)  the provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,050,000 
on a grant basis for the Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 
2). If the Board approves ADB providing technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $1,550,000, the President, acting under the authority delegated by 
the  Board,  will  approve  ADB  administering  the  balance  of  the  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant 
basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for the 
Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 2).  
(ii)  to facilitate ADB cooperation with other development partners in support of the 
CDDE program regarding (a) the selection and recruitment of consultants for the 
Asia-Pacific CDDE program referred to in paragraph 17 herein, in accordance 
with the rules and procedures of UNDP; and (b) the procurement of consulting 
services for the CDDE program in ADB member and nonmember countries, 
provided Directors representing not less than two-thirds of the total voting power 
of the ADB members agree; to facilitate ADB cooperation with other development 
partners in support of the CDDE program implementation. 
                                                 
20 The program steering committee will be comprised of representatives from two other development partners, one 
legislature, three governments, and two civil society organizations.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Governance  Assessments  and  Good  Practice  Guidance  for  Governance  and 
Capacity Development 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  will  provide  about  20  person-months  of 
international consulting services and 65 person-months of national consulting services for (i) 
undertaking country and sector governance risk assessments for selected country partnership 
strategies (CPS), and (ii) preparing and updating guidance for Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
staff on preparation of risk assessments. Specific sector and country expertise will also be 
required.  
 
2.  The  consultants  will  undertake  the  following  activities:  (i)  conduct  governance  risk 
assessments in accordance with Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP 
II)  guidelines;  and  (ii)  research,  develop,  and  document  methodologies  for  undertaking 
governance risk assessments in public financial management, procurement, and combating 
corruption at national, subnational, and sector levels. The specific consulting requirements will 
be refined further on the basis of the CPSs and sectors selected, and the comparative strengths 
and weaknesses of each country team. 
 
B.  Capacity Development for Development Effectiveness Program 
 
3.  Five  principles  underpin  the  Capacity  Development  for  Development  Effectiveness 
(CDDE) Program: (i) the program will provide support services only in response to country 
demand; (ii) the program is complementary to ongoing capacity development initiatives; (iii) all 
support will be integrated into ongoing processes at the country level to ensure sustainability 
and added value; (iv) the program will proactively seek to identify needs and interests at the 
country  level  through  consultation;  and  (v)  the  program  will  seek  to  support  capacity 
development through south–south partnerships wherever possible.  
 
4.  The program will provide services in three areas: 
 
(i)  Peer-to-Peer Services—Strengthening Collaboration in the Region 
 
(a)  Facilitating subregional and thematic peer exchange with technical and 
small  grant  assistance  and  web-based  communications  to  support 
collaboration.  
(b)  Improving access to evidence and analysis from the implementation of 
aid policy in the Asia and Pacific region.  
(c)  Providing  an  annual  forum  for  aid  effectiveness  policy  makers  and 
practitioners to exchange experience and strategize across countries.  
 
(ii)  Knowledge  Management  and  Help  Desk  Services—Connecting  People  and 
Knowledge 
 
(a)  Improving  access  to  knowledge  and  expertise  through  a  cutting-edge 
knowledge  management  portal,  www.aideffectiveness.org,  including  e-
library services and 'find an expert' services. 
(b)  Providing a help desk that gives rapid responses to ad hoc queries on 
how to access analysis, expertise, policy process, and event information.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iii)  Capacity  Development  Services—Assessing  Needs  and  Strategies  to  Meet 
Them 
 
(a)  Accessing capacity assessment and capacity development strategy tools 
and good practices. 
(b)  Supporting capacity development responses through peer collaboration.  
 
 
C.  ADB/Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  Anticorruption 
Initiative 
 
5.  The  TA  will  provide  secretariat  and  publication  expertise  to  the  ADB/OECD 
Anticorruption Initiative as follows: 
 
  1.  Governance and Anticorruption Specialist (national, 24 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant must have a technical background and familiarity with, and relevant 
experience in, the governance and anticorruption activities of ADB and in the Asia and Pacific 
region  to  provide  professional,  research,  and  administrative  support  to  ADB's  Public 
Management,  Governance  and  Participation  Division  in  managing  the  ADB/OECD 
Anticorruption Initiative. The specialist will (i) organize and provide logistical support for steering 
group  meetings,  regional  conferences,  and  training  seminars;  (ii)  provide  technical  and 
administrative assistance in organizing and coordinating with development agencies and partner 
institutions on anticorruption initiatives in the region; (iii) coordinate with ADB resident missions 
and developing member country (DMC) heads of government to identify DMC participants in 
regional policy dialogues, in-country consultations, steering group meetings, and anticorruption 
workshops;  (iv)  communicate  with  proposed  resource  speakers,  participants,  and 
representatives of international organizations at bilateral meetings; ensure their availability; and 
coordinate their papers for presentation; (v) assist in the preparation of speeches, papers, 
presentation materials, and seminar tool kits for steering group meetings, conferences, and 
training seminars; (vi) assist DMC participants and resource persons invited by ADB with their 
travel arrangements and other matters related to their participation at meetings, dialogues, and 
workshops; (vii) coordinate with partner institutions, and be a part of the secretariat that will 
oversee logistics and other administrative matters; (viii) provide research assistance relating to 
anticorruption issues, and prepare responses to queries and concerns of DMC governments, 
anticorruption  agencies,  and  international  institutions;  and  (ix)  provide  initial  editing,  and 
coordinate  with  the  copy  editors  and  contributors  regarding  the  editing,  revisions,  and 
finalization of the training seminar papers and proceedings, review the editing of the seminar 
papers, prepare the necessary requirements, and supervise the typesetting and printing of 
publications. The specialist may participate in selected workshops and meetings associated with 
the initiative. 
 
  2.  Copy Editors (various, 30 person days) 
 
7.  The consultants, to be hired as needed, will have editorial experience and a thorough 
knowledge  of  ADB’s  publishing  requirements.  The  consultants  will  (i)  copyedit  selected 
conference  papers  and  publications  to  improve  their  overall  presentation  and  enhance 
readability by ensuring consistency in style and format among the various sections according to 
ADB’s Handbook on Style and Usage; (ii) incorporate comments and required corrections in the 
text; (iii) edit preliminary and other materials (foreword, executive summary, list of participants,

Appendix 3  11 
etc.);  and  (iv)  prepare  manuscripts  in  Microsoft  Word  format,  ensuring  readiness  for  final 
typesetting and formatting by ADB. 
 
D.  Capacity Development Assessments 
 
8.  The TA will provide about 7 person-months of international consulting services and 40 
person-months of national consulting services in undertaking capacity assessments in priority 
CPS sectors. Specific sector and country expertise will also be required. The specific consulting 
requirements will be refined further on the basis of the CPSs and sectors selected and the 
comparative strengths and weaknesses of each country team. 
 
9.  The  consultants  will  undertake  the  following  activities:  (i)  develop  and  document  a 
methodology for undertaking capacity assessments in association with the governance risk 
assessments  in  public  financial  management,  procurement,  and  corruption    at  national, 
subnational,  and  sector  levels;  (ii)  support  the  Public  Management,  Governance  and 
Participation Division in consultations with country teams to develop an approach to ensure 
capacity development diagnostic and analytical tools support the implementation of GACAP II; 
(iii) together with the country team, assess the depth and quality of existing capacity diagnostics 
at the national, subnational, and sector levels; (iv) together with DMC officials and the ADB 
country team, undertake capacity assessments with a particular focus on ensuring that capacity 
gaps  in  the  risk  mitigation  strategies  at  the  national,  subnational,  and  sector  levels  are 
understood, and achievable capacity development actions are formulated; (v) provide relevant 
input into CPSs; (vi) design a framework for assessing the proposed use of program lending for 
the relevant sector, national, or subnational government on the basis of an assessment of 
capacity; and (vii) update the methodology on the basis of experience gained.
